embeds.title: Dancing Master
embeds.description:
Rare Power / 2 (1) :energy_champ: / The Champ / Downfall

The first time you use a Finisher each turn, gain :energy_champ: and draw 1 card.

messages.content: This card is pretty fun, can fuel <gladiators manual> and increase overall consistency. Good with <rope-a-dope> and <improvising> makes getting this to work easier.

embeds.title: Gladiators Manual
embeds.description:
Rare Relic / The Champ / Downfall

Whenever you play a Combo, a Finisher, and enter a **Stance** in the same turn, gain 1 **Strength** :p_strength: and **Dexterity** :p_dexterity:.
*Try everything - something will stick.*

embeds.description:

Gain 12 **Block** :p_block:.
Next turn, gain :energy_champ:  ( :energy_champ:) and draw 2 cards.
:finisher:   **Finisher**

embeds.title: Improvising
embeds.description:
Rare Power / 1 (0) :energy_champ: / The Champ / Downfall

At the start of the turn, if you are not in a **Stance**, enter a random **Stance**.

messages.content: I think a lot of people see champ and they pidgeon hole themselves into vigor stacking but while its really strong its awful in act 4 especially if neow gets buffer. Cards like this can help you pivot away from vigor and hopefully into something else.
Champ is the only character where god of life is worse than beat of death, imo.
tbh you can kinda just go dupe pot+glad form+ or two glad form (one can be from power pot if you can’t find dupe pot) and win neow like that
glad form does kinda hurt in a decent bit of hallways but champ’s hallway game is strong enough that it’s prolly fine
That requires finding gladiator form, and taking it where its near useless in every other situation.
And having a second one.
Both upgraded.
it’s not that hard to find dupe pot though
you may need to take some damage to preserve it to act4
Or lug around a dupe pot the whole run losing on a potion slot.
but usually it’s not like you have the dupe pot from act1 anyway
Ok so headbutt helps dancing master too with either stance entries or finishers
Forgot to menion
holy shit all the next discussions are my beta art
im famous
<revel>

embeds.title: Revel
embeds.description:
Uncommon Skill / 3 (2) :energy_gremlins: / The Gremlins / Downfall

Gain :energy_gremlins: for each living Gremlin.

messages.content: Champ only has a modest amount of card draw ever since circumvent was nerfed and has always had a lack of energy generation thats renewable. This card solves both problems, draws a card and gives an energy all at the low cost of playing a finisher card, something you want to eventually be doing every turn of the run because finishers are all quite strong.  Dancing master is not a card you can take at the beginning of the game though, just because it will be a curse until the later half of act 2; unless you have snecko eye.
tbh idk exactly what to say about this card, except that it is consistent draw on a character that lacks it
drawesome
Does calm depict gain 2 energy as the finisher bonus
Champ with fear no evil and moment of truth?

Evaluating this is very tricky. The effect is obviously great, and both the card draw and energy are quite valuable on champ (very little card draw in their kit, tons of powerful but expensive cards). You can even proc this powers effect on the same turn you cast it, refunding both the energy and the card if it's upgraded. It also naturally helps champ to have a bit more gas in the tank and scale during a fight, which is often one of hardest parts of building a champ deck. The difficult lies in casting a finisher each turn, which requires drawing one, and being in a stance/having a stance entry card in hand. Awkwardly though, every turn that you play a finisher, you are leaving a stance, making it even harder to proc this effect again next turn, which can lead to some real consistency issues. I think the card can be excellent, but it requires a lot of commitment to get to that point, and is very situational on having tons of stance entries and finishers.

Improvising comes to mind as perhaps the easiest way to get around the drawback, but that card is often quite difficult to take in the first place, as it's really low impact, doesn't work properly with ultimate stance, and really wants you to already have a bunch of finishers, and even then is still fairly slow. Needing to get two rares together in the same deck to make them both good and consistent is often asking for trouble, and can lead to chicken and egg type problems where it's hard to take either card first because you don't know whether or not you will find the other piece to support it. You could also use runic pyramid to excellent effect to get around both drawbacks, as it would make it much easier to consistently have new stance entries and finishers for each turn. 

This will just get in the way of your better solutions for acts 1 and 2 (frontloading), and having the right balance of finishers to stance entries will be tough at that point as well. By act 3, it shoud be clear if this makes sense to take.
Headbutt is very takeable early and helps on both sides of that in my experience. I tend towards technical jig a lot so it fits well in my typical decks.
There's also moment of truth.
Which becomes like adrenaline.

The upgrade is pretty solid, but not a high priority unless you are very good at proccing this on the same turn you cast it. Any source of additional card draw from relics can help here, with snecko eye being likely the best, as many finishers are expensive cards. Mummified hand can help you have enough energy to proc this on turn one as well. Overall, I think the card is in a good place balance wise, and I generally like having powerful but situational cards available in the card pool, as they help runs to feel quite different. I just think that champ is so overcentralized on vigor/multihit burst damage combos that a card like this can sometimes feel a little difficult to find the right runs for it.
I think the only finshers worth having "normally" are execute, rope a dope, and moment of truth. Take it on is takeable sometimes maybe.
Steel edge and piledriver just aren't good
you mean <bring it on>?

embeds.title: Steel Edge
embeds.description:
Rare Attack / X :energy_champ: / The Champ / Downfall

Deal 8 (11) damage X times.
:finisher:   **Finisher**

messages.content: I think this card is pretty decent, its easy to use it as your dedicated attack in a one shot deck. You need 4 energy, but this lets you use your vigor 4 times easily killing almost anything. It does compete with other cards for this role though and steel edge doesn't do well ageist neow
This is stasis engine done right. On a character that wants it more with a real upgrade and an easier condition.
Champ really likes having that 4th energy, and also really likes having more draw (champ only has like.... 4 cards that are draw neutral or better)
<arena prep type=card> <moment of truth> <refreshments> and I think I am missing 1 more. Also has <rope-a-dope> for next turn draw.

messages.content: Champ needs a common draw card, in my opinion every character should have at least 1.
and I mean at minimum draw neutral

The lack of draw and defensive scaling options is why I don't really like champ. It's very dependent on getting certain cards, but it still can survive act 1 and a decent amount of act 2 on the fact that the character is fundamentally extremely strong and only has these few things holding him back.
backstep is a common card
